main-use-cases: Note-taking;As a knowledge base (including technical, non-fiction and encyclopaedic content);Worldbuilding (e.g. for role-playing games);Programming
value-of-tw:
Develop SAP/legacy systems work instructions and task sheets for specific job classifications.
Used to document and maintain status from daily production control briefings  

Knowledge base for gaming
Maintain data driven performance metrics for guild.
tw-ability-level: I have customised TiddlyWiki through options and plugins;I am comfortable using WikiText widgets (e.g. <$transclude>, <$list>...);I have written custom HTML;I have written custom CSS styles
save-method: Single-file wiki through web browser with Download Saver (default saving mechanism);Multi-file wiki served through Node.js

tw-customisations: Mostly stylesheets and a few specific macros/procedures to meet a need.   Most are developed from tiddlytalk discussions or direct answers to my inquiries.
project-strengths:
Consistency of TW over the years.
The tiddlytalk community
Plugin developers
tiddlyhost supporter, although my usage has waned since moving to my own server
Excited for the future server versions in work
project-weaknesses:
I used TW for 20 years during my work life, and the portability of a single file wiki was key.  Moving away from a single file would have ended my use.  Although in my retired life and changing technology, I have embraced the nodeJS version.

Put the name issue to rest. Hell I like Tiddlywiki or TWx.  To much discussion continues and distracts.

Learning JS I guess would lead me to contriubute more, but I am a python hack.
ok-to-publish: Yes, I am happy for my responses to be published
